column10: What are the other main security-related challenges you're facing when developing and deploying Web content?

I don't think that there's an official or trusted source that developers can refer to when it website security comes in question. A Google search for the best website security practices provides you with a bunch of results, and each website recommends doing different types of things! It is a mess, honestly. I think MDN Web Docs should organize this to make the best and most recommended website security practices easily available and readable.

Minimising dependencies and complexity. The modern web is rotten to the core: PKIs, CAs, ASN1.0, dodgy elliptic curve constants, ad surveillance networks, paywalls, clickbait... We should just trash the whole thing and start from scratch.  [PII redacted - 1]

Trying to implement a strict-csp header, especially when trying to be compliant with third-party scripts.  When using an allowlist CSP header I frequently need to loosen up security due to third party requiring `unsafe-eval` for example.  Relaying all security related matters in FE to my frontend team. Especially CSP / CORS still seem to be "hard" to understand concepts.  Firefox/Safari not supporting TrustTypes OOTB. Now requires a polyfill, which kills adoptation.

Full stack reference design that is GDPR compliant, and compliant with regional regulations. It's more about architecture than specific web features. References from Mozilla on this would be fantastic. We could then point regulators to those references, and with time they would start understanding exactly what is and isn't catered for in those designs, and how each element maps to the framework they are evaluating.

Lack of documentation on how browsers handle/verify server and especially client certificates. Which fields are allowed/used in a certificate, how?   How to tell a browser to use a CA cert only to validate certs for a specific domain?  How to import a client cert in Firefox on Android?

Mostly implementing authentication flows in modern webapps is very challenging as there are not always enough options or libraries for some frameworks and making your own auth flow from scratch is even worse as you'll need the knowledge to make it secure enough and it goes way beyond simply hashing a password. I have to admit eventho it's just clientside, browsers do simplify security by alot yet still really making it secure. Honesty there's no best way, but repeating simple steps to eliminate common security threats and then improving them with your own code does make it alot better.

Security is too complicated to be woven into every part of the development process.  Progress on functionality must be made, and this will at times require doing things that aren't in accordance with best practice.  This phase of development should be considered prototyping, however it is unlikely that an app will truly go through all necessary prototyping before starting work on the final product, and eventually some of the functionality constructed will be required for further prototyping etc.  Unfortunately, it's going to be very difficult to go back and fill all the holes you left.

First issue, while keeping underlying stacks up to date is important keeping the apps secure while relying on ever more libraries and frameworks are increasingly hard. Next issue, is not just about hacking but keeping intellectual property secure from corporate actors while hosting on cloud platforms. E.g. app code being scanned to build AI models while explicitly not asking permissions of owners.
Permissions, Authorization, Not properly doing a threat model.
